title: NL-Graphs: A Hybrid Approach toward Interactively Querying Semantic Data

author: Suvodeep Mazumdar, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

segmentation: Good afternoon everyone and we will move from the usability from of description logics to the usability of user interfaces and my name is Super Deep Mazumdar and I'm working in the University of Sheffield in the organization's information and Knowledge Group and I will be presenting our approach towards hybrid hybrid approach towards querying semantic data.
So as I said, we we.

Be focusing a lot on users and our study is a part of a longer term user centered design approach and we've already had several iterations of design and what we present here is one of the final iterations we've reached to at this point of time.
And well, basically, if we look at users.
They are the key persons involved in the systems that we develop.

So when we look at semantic search systems, what we actually mean by it is a semantic search system should allow users to satisfy their information needs and a big part of user satisfaction is performance of search systems.
Of course presentation of results but also the query approach.
So what kind of approach is used by the users to actually access the information that they're interested in?
And as a result of that usability and user experience, experience is very important and that has been largely ignored and I think we need more to focus on users.
So when I talk about query approaches, what do I mean by query approaches?
There have been several types of query approaches developed in the past.
Each type employs their own interaction mechanism as well as the they employ different formalisms.
For example, natural language in their systems form based systems, query formal query approaches.
And often each approach is very task specific or application specific.
For example natural keyword based approach or natural language systems are useful to help users identify.
Relevant instances formal query approaches, on the other hand, are more useful for complicated queries.
Complex tasks such as negation, group by and so on, and most semantic Web applications focus on only one approach.

So to illustrate this, we look at the formality Continuum, which is a scale that has been proposed by Kaufman, and the idea is that the more towards the left you go, the more natural your actions are.
So towards the left you have natural language and towards the right you have formal language.
So any system which is towards the left follows a natural language approach, whereas the ones towards the right follows a formal approach and.
As you can see, the degree of formality decreases as you move from left to right.
So to exemplify this, we look at one example which is power, Aqua and power acquired requires users to enter a question and analyzing the question which is written in natural language.
It identifies concepts and then provides a result based on a sparkle query that was generated.
Critics, on the other hand, uses a slightly restricted approach where the user is required to start their sentences.
Are there questions with indicative keywords?
So, for example, which what, how many, how much, and so on?
Ginseng is a system where the user start typing the queries and the system.
Previously upon indexing, the data starts highlighting queries that might be of interest.
And that is slightly restricted, slightly more restrictive, so we move towards the formal query approach.
Case Search, which is a form based query approach, provides users with a form where users can fill in the forms fields to indicate what their user interest is.
And finally 2.
It's the complete right side.

We have sparkle text entry points in linked data endpoints or systems like Semantic crystal, which are highly visual, but which end up asking users to interact with the concepts with the ontology views and ad queries and then add more restrictions and essentially building a sparkle query and then users can send off the queries.
So what we can see is that we have a spectrum of query approaches, all placed at distinct points within the formality Continuum.
So what are the issue?
Other motivations with these so with each query approach comes a set of advantages and disadvantages.

Now there was a, there was an evaluation done by Albert where he at all where they compared experts and casual users, and it was found that the natural language approach and the view based approach was the most liked by both kind of users.
So natural language approach has a certain list of positivities but as well as comes with negative.

Implications, for example, prior experience with Google like applications help users familiarize with natural language systems, so it's really quick and easy to write keywords and questions and get quick answers, but that creates less support for complex queries.
On the other hand, view based approach provides really good support in complex queries, but and also allows users to visualize the search space.
But there is a lot of time and effort required to formulate queries.

We developed a view based approach and we tried it out with a set of users right at the bottom there's a reference and what we found out is after we realized that the view based approach took a lot of time and effort, we realize we thought that maybe it might be a learnability issue, so why not let the users try allowed the system for a period of time and then see if they still need some time to familiarize with it, and we realize that.

Even though there was an improvement in user satisfaction and performance overtime, but users still needed time to formulate queries, an effort to formulate queries and observation during the evaluation was that users used a lot of keyword based searches, so that was another indication to us to motivate us in working towards the direction now.
So what is the view based approach?

We developed a system called effective graphs and effective graphs is essentially a node link visualization and where every node is a concept and in this example we're looking at DB pedia data and the user starts with the thing on the top left and the user looks at the thing and each concept is visualized as a pie chart which represents the distribution of the instances.
Within the subclasses of that concept.
So from thing the user start to see a pie chart of what are the main concepts in the data set.

Now when they find something interesting, for example on the top they found place to be interesting, they click on place and a new node is formed which shows a new distribution of all the subclasses within place, and then they go further down to natural place where they find another list of distribution of subclasses and they go down to the Lake, and then they decide.
Now they want to look at something else and they look at persons via agent.
And as they do that they kind of get.
The links being shown so the links started to be discovered, we can see new links.
This kind of link, which is a satellite link which represents data type properties and links between nodes, represent object properties, so I'll give an example where.
A user.

A user is exploring just randomly exploring the data set and the user finds something like species which might be relevant to the user and the user can see that there is only one major concept in there which has most of the data and that was eukaryote and then they go onto plants and then they find far flowering plants and they realize that OK, grape is something that might be of interest to me.
Now when they do that, they find that there is nothing else to go too so they can go back to the original.

Concept or they can look into grape and they can see a context behind that and they see that there was one link that might might have been important to them, which was an object relation and they find when they click on that then you can see another node being created and then they say that OK.
I found this link which is quite important to me, or which is quite interesting to me.
So they select that link and then the highlighted.
Now when the highlighted they express it as OK.
I'm interested in this.
Let me have a look at the data that's contained in there.
And then they find more satellite objects interesting.

These are data properties, so then they can identify objects like that visual objects and visually build their queries to find the data that they are interested in, and then they can apply restrictions on top of individual data properties and over here the user is saying that OK, wine regions need to have more than 5 grape producing vineyards, and then they when they press search they find.
A list of results.
And they can click on the data to find more information from DB pedia.
So gay.
Given an introduction to a visual approach of querying.
The issue was that users could still take a lot of time to explore data, come into a data point, and then find relevant instances.
But that still took users quite a lot of time and effort, so how can we simplify this approach?
What we decided was because we've identified that natural language is one of the most like systems or one of the most like approach.
Why not combine natural language and a view based system?
So what we did was we plugged in a natural language module on top.

To the view based approach and what this enables us to do is users can enter a question or a set of keywords and those set of keywords or questions can then be analyzed and we can find relevant concepts that might be of interest to the user and when they find relevant concepts that are interesting, they can visualize the search space around the concepts to find data properties or object properties linked to other concepts and then they can identify that as queries and build very quick queries.
So essentially they remove.
They reduce the exploratory time if they have a specific need for information, they just type out the query and then they reach the concepts of interest.
So.
We took natural language system that we that was developed by Albert Way and we took the graph based system.
We plugged it in in the hybrid web query approach.
Now the advantage is as I said, it builds on the advantages of either approach but negates the disadvantage.
The support given by natural language system negates the long time taken by view based approach.
So an example of.
How it might work in a hybrid approach is, for example, a user has a question in mind and the question is.
Which River Cross does the Brooklyn Bridge cross?

And that's a very generic question, and when the user enters the query, it does some analysis on that and at this point the system has realized that OK, there are two concepts that the user is talking about.

One is River and the other is bridge and the system also analyzes that the bridge, the specific bridge that the user is talking about is the Brooklyn Bridge, and it sets that as a restriction on the concept of bridge.

No, it couldn't understand what does cross mean, because even though there is a link between the two objects, sometimes the natural language systems will not be perfect enough to identify all the concepts.
All the properties that the user has mentioned and that is why a visual approach is useful because the user can visualize the search space.
So the user then selects the concept that is of interest and then identifies that as a query object and then selects that and then enter search and when they do that they get the result East River.

So essentially the user has reduced the exploration time significantly by using a natural language query, But then uses the visualization to understand what concepts are around that query to make a final list of final query using a visual method.
No.
How did we evaluate it?
It's of course very important to evaluate it, so we tried to.
What we realized is we've already evaluated our approach in a pre in our previous work.
So we want in this evaluation we wanted to focus on the hybrid approach as a new query mechanism and we wanted to see how much support is provided by the approach to users.
So we the methodology we used was we initially contacted a lot of experts and casual users.
We contacted people in a software development firm and we contacted a lot of people within the Department of Computer Science and we also sent an email to everyone.
Every staff and student to the University of Sheffield and then we 24 people agreed to participate in our experiment, 12 casual users and 12 experts.

And the mean age was 31 years and they were aged between 18 and 50 three years and experiment started with short demonstration of a scenario based example and the users were given a similar similar scenario where we've shown how to build a query and then they were given some time to familiarize with the system.
Death.
Then given 5 questions which we identified from the quality data set and each question has a different level of difficulty and we identify these questions one was when was Capcom founded.
What is Bruce Carver die from who was the wife of US President Lincoln and so on and so forth.
And we identify these questions because from the previous experiment, I think the experiment is described here.

These questions were giving problems to the natural language systems and the reason is that there are sometimes natural language systems would not pick up things like founded because the relations in DB Pedia might not be the same or might be something different.
How?
We analyze the evaluation was we took subjective and objective data.
Objective data constituted input time, number of attempts, success rate and so on.

Subjective data was mostly post evaluation questionnaire and we had a system usability scale that users filled up and then we had another extra extended questionnaire where the users were asked questions like the question how did you find the query construction process?
What do you like about the hybrid approach?
So these were very open ended question.
What did you dislike about the approach and the users were given another type of questionnaire which was the aesthetics questionnaire.
We didn't.
We found we thought that this would be out of the scope of this paper, so we haven't discussed this.
But this is another aspect that we have used to develop our systems.
So.
Briefly, what were the results?
We found that overall experts like the system more than casuals and that was kind of expected because experts know more about the data.
Experts knew about DV pedia.
Experts are very happy with graph graph based data and they understand that very well.
Success rate.
Most of all of the users were able to satisfactory get the results.
And mostly on one attempt only.
So over here we would like to mention that a lot of the times when we do information retrieval, evaluations or or semantic interfaces evaluations, we always look at the data which we feel is right.
And if the users are accessing their butt over here, what we focused on was after completion of a task, is the user happy with the answer they get.
It might not be the right answer that we think is, but is the user happy?
And that is very important for us.
Because we are providing a service to users and its user satisfaction comes as a result of that.
So we found that the query construction process was pretty much effortless for most users, most users were positively commenting on the usability and support provided by the hybrid approach.
4 users felt some issues with the system.
They found that the user was complicated and unintuitive.
They've asked us why are there more steps than like a Google like approach?
Why would I need to do so much?

When I can search data in on Google directly and one user mentioned, it seemed an extra step to get to your answer rather than just typing in a search and appearing in results, and that is important for our community because we need to think how to communicate the essence of semantics and the essence of interfaces and approaches like this to users better.
Some more, some users mentioned that they might need a more assistance and training.
Most surprising to us was that experts took longer to formulate queries than casual users, and the reason we felt and during the experiment we observed was that.
Experts seem to follow logic and follow a methodology.

Methodological approach towards building the queries so they always wanted to confirm that am I doing the right thing and then once every step they did they also wanted to check the sparkle query that was being generated.
They wanted to check more details about the about the technical aspects of the system.
We did analysis on the kind of queries and what kind of data was being generated off it.
So we took input time and we took the number of attempts and as I discussed before that most of the Times users got the results in one attempt.

But over here we can see that there are two queries Bruce Springsteen, an Alaska and two queries over here Bruce Springsteen, an Alaska which took the longest time and which took relatively more time.
More number of queries and all of the time you can see that the experts.
Which are on the right take longer than the casuals.
Now the.
These were give me all cities in Alaska.
More than 110,000 inhabitants.
And issues where that people were asking questions like.
Give me Alaskan cities with over 10,000 inhabitants.
An Alaskan wasn't recognized by our natural language system and therefore people need to enter queries manually.
The there are some issues with the data.
As well in DB pedia we found that Alaska was recognized as an administrative region which has a link to city.

But the link that they needed to select was is part of and users couldn't understand if is part of is the right term to use or is the right relation to use to build their query and sometimes users needed to enter numerical constraints which also took a fairly long.

The second question show me all songs from Bruce Springsteen released between a particular date was also requiring users to enter manual queries through a calendar interface, so that took some time because users needed to select the date from here the year from here and then add it to query.
So given our experiment and results.
In summary the question is, does hybrid approach work?
Does hybrid approach work with along large data set?
We think it works.
We found users to be very satisfied with how it is high system usability scores indicate usability and usefulness, and we have a lot of plans to continue.
Take this work forward.
For example design, redesign it a bit.
We also look into longer term studies and also with larger.
Lot of cruel users and also we would like to see how we can improve the natural language system and plug in other natural language systems from other interfaces and see if we can improve it.
So I did.
Thank you for your attention and I'll be very happy to take some questions.
